Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
Our digestive system produces an assailable, (1)/ nutrient-rich liquid that builds and (2)/ nourish our first body tissue, plasma. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence.
It should be ‘nourishes’ instead of ‘nourish’.
The word nourish means provide with the food or other substances necessary for growth ad nourishes is the 3rd person present verb of nourish.
Since the entire sentence is framed in 3rd person present tense, the word nourish should also be used in the same tense.
Hence, option 3 is correct.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
Acquired immunity is the result of an (1)/ interaction with our new environment and (2)/ proper digestion of all that we take off. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence. The word ‘off’ at the end of the sentence is wrong.
It should be ‘in’ rather than ‘off’. The context of the sentence is that acquired immunity is a result of our interaction with our environment and proper digestion of everything that we eat or goes inside us.
While ‘off’ is adverb that means to removed or separated from something therefore it is wrong in this context.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
Just as we nourishes the body, (1)/ we need to nurture the soul to connect to the creative (2)/ power of the universe and to manifest joy in our lives. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution: The error is in part 1 of the sentence. It should be ‘nourish’ instead of ‘nourishes’ .The sentence is framed in simple present tense and ‘nourishes’ is the 3<sup>rd</sup> person present of nourish. Therefore it is incorrect in this context.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
If we objectively ponder on the mystery behind (1)/ miseries, we find that as long as we restrict (2)/ ourselves to the means of happiness, we are left in the lurch. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 1 of the sentence. It should be ‘ponder over’ rather than ‘ponder on’, over makes more sense in this context.
Ponder means think about (something) carefully, especially before making a decision or reaching a conclusion. Ponder is usually followed by over and upon in English grammar.
We think over something carefully but we cannot think ‘on’ something that is grammatically incorrect.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
Our sole prayer should be to be blessing with (1)/ a spiritual awakening that is the real (2)/ source of peace, bliss and contentment. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 1 of the sentence.
Key Points
Reading the sentence we find that:
  • It should be blessed instead of 'blessing'
  • In the given sentence the word blessing is used after to be.
  • As a rule, when 'to be' form is preceded by a model (Should) the verb used should be past participle.
  • The past participle of 'bless' is blessed.
  • Therefore blessing is replaced with blessed.
Thus we find that the error lies in part 1 of the sentence.
The correct sentence will be: 'Our sole prayer should be to be blessed with a spiritual awakening that is the real source of peace, bliss and contentment.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
My tool has always been humour because (1)/ it's the most entertaining way to put any ideology (2)/ cross, and it's fun, positive, and healing. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence. It should be ‘across’ instead of ‘cross’. Across is the right word in the context of the sentence. Across means expressing position or orientation.
Cross means pass in an opposite or different direction; intersect. Therefore across is the right answer.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
When a student works on a mathematical problem, (1)/ he comes to a stage beyond which he do not (2)/ know how to proceed, and where he is in doubt and perplexity. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution: The error is in part 2 of the sentence. It should be ‘does not’ instead of ‘do not’. Since the sentence is frames in 3<sup>rd</sup> person present tense the word ‘do’ does not fit the context. ‘Do’ means to perform an action and does is the 3<sup>rd</sup> person singular present of the verb ‘do’. So ‘does’ is grammatically correct.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
When one stops being optimistic, one believes that he/ she (1)/ is worthless, and stops hoping for a better future, (2)/ it is only then that the moment of actual failure happened. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence. It should be ‘happens’ instead of ‘happened’. The sentence is framed in present tense.
The word ‘happened’ is the past participle of happen which means to occur and ‘happens’ is the present participle of happen. Therefore the correct word in this context is ‘happens’.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
Looking forward to something (1)/ in anticipation is what helps us (2)/ moving forward in life. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence. The verb ‘help’ is used with infinitive: ‘to move’ or just ‘move’ rather than ‘moving’. The correct sentence would be ‘helps us to move forward in life’.
Infinitive is as if the verb phrase puts on the costume of a noun, adjective or adverb and plays the role of a part of speech other than itself.
Any verb that is preceded by the word 'to' is an infinitive.
Therefore ‘to move’ makes grammatical sense here.
Hence, option 3 is correct.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
When the self is not enlightened, (1)/ it is fundamental identified with the notion of (2)/ difference, unaware of its primordial unity. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 2.
Key Points
  • It should be ‘fundamentally’ instead of ‘fundamental’.
  • In the given sentence before the verb identified we should use an adverb.
  • The word fundamental is an adjective that means forming a necessary base or core; of central importance.
  • While fundamentally is an adverb that means in central or primary respects, it is used to make an emphatic statement about the basic truth of something.
  • Therefore the word fundamentally makes more sense in this context and is grammatically correct.
  • Thus the correct answer is part 2 as it has an error.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
When we are able to stop, pause and think (1)/ more about our actions, words and thoughts, we begin (2)/ to see the cause and affect more clearly. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution: The error is in part 3 of the sentence. It should be ‘effect’ instead of ‘affect’. The word ‘affect’ means to have an effect on; make a difference to. While the word ‘effect’ means a change which is a result or consequence of an action or other cause. Therefore the word effect makes more sense in the context of the sentence.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
We may only be here in the blink of an eye, (1)/ but the way we live our lives will stay (2)/ with the universe forever. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The sentence has an error in the first part of the sentence.
'In the blink of eye' means quickly, in a short amount of time.
Example sentence: In the blink of an eye, he was gone.
The sentence suggests that we are here for a short while ie. we will be gone from the world in a short amount of time, so the sentence should be:
We will be gone in the blink of an eye but the way we live our lives will stay with the universe forever.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
I’ve learned what really counts in life, in the end, is not how many toys we have (1)/ collected or how much money we’ve accumulated, but how many of our (2)/ talents we have liberated and used for a purpose that add value to this world. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution: The error is in part 3 of the sentence. It should be ‘adds’ instead of ‘add’. The verb ‘add’ does not appear to agree with the singular subject ‘a purpose’. So if we change the verb form for the subject-verb agreement then the sentence becomes grammatically correct.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
For a man to change radically, fundamentally, (1)/ there must be a mutation in a every (2)/ brain cell of his mind. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 2 of the sentence.
Key Points
  • The use of the article 'a' creates the error in this part.
  • When no determiner is used with the noun, we use articles with it.
  • Every is a determiner. So there is no need of using an article before it.
The correct sentence - For a man to change radically, fundamentally, there must be a mutation in every brain cell of his mind.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
Character build should be an integral part (1)/ of every aspect of schooling and learning as it (2)/ equips one to find long-term solutions to life’s challenges. (3)/ No Error (4)
Solution: The error is in part 1 of the sentence. It should be ‘building’ instead of ‘build’. The word building makes more grammatical sense here than build. ‘Building’ is a noun that means the creation or development of something over a period of time. While ‘build’ means make or become stronger or more intense.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
Problem-solving, decision making and conflict (1)/ resolution are all important processes (2)/ to developing good moral character. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence. It appears that the preposition ‘to’ is incorrect in this context. It should rather be ‘in’ or ‘for’.
The correct phrase should be ‘all important processes in developing good moral character’.
Prepositions are function words that indicate how a noun or noun phrase relates to the rest of the sentence.
Prepositions should be used carefully because sometimes changing a preposition can change the entire meaning or context of the sentence or phrase.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
A person operating at the pre-conventional level of moral reasoning (1)/ considers any decision or ethical dilemma from the point of view of avoiding (2)/ personal harm, losing or seek personal gain. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence. It should be ‘seeking’ rather than ‘seek’.
The word ‘seek’ is grammatically incorrect in this context. Seek means an attempt to find something. While seeking is the present participle of seek. Present participle is a participle that ends with ‘ing’, used in continuous tense.
Since the sentence is framed in continuous tense the word seek should also follow the same tense.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
Rapid developments in modern medicine has (1)/ conquered many diseases and consequently (2)/ the death rate has decreased. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 1 of the sentence. The singular verb ‘has’ does not appear to agree with the plural subject ‘developments’.
We should change the verb form of the sentence for subject-verb agreement. It should rather be ‘have’.
A plural subject of the sentence requires a plural verb.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
True positive thinking starts by embracing reality in its myriad (1)/ shapes and forms; it involves the ability to feel negative emotions when you have to, (2)/ and still maintain hope enough to keep on going. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence.
Key Points
  • It should rather be ‘maintain enough hope’ rather than ‘maintain hope enough.’ The latter phrase is grammatically incorrect.
  • Enough can be used both as an adjective and as an adverb.
  • When 'enough' is used as an adjective it is placed before the noun it is qualifying.
    • Example: They had enough cash for a one-way ticket.
    • 'hope' is a noun and 'enough' is qualifying it.
  • When 'enough' is used as an adverb, it is placed after the verb it is qualifying.
    • Example: I was old enough to work and earn money.
​Additional Information
  • Enough can also be used as a pronoun:
    Example: Although the U.K. says efforts are being made, they are not doing enough.
​Thus, the correct sentence is: True positive thinking starts by embracing reality in its myriad shapes and forms; it involves the ability to feel negative emotions when you have to, and still maintain enough hope to keep ongoing.

Question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select ‘No Error’.
A business venture or one’s own personal life has greater chances (1)/ of experiencing success and fulfilment, (2)/ if the outlook is more temperate to indifferent or radical. (3)/ No error (4)
Solution:
The error is in part 3 of the sentence. It should be ‘than indifferent’ instead of ‘to indifferent’. It appears that the preposition ‘to’ is incorrect in this context.
Prepositions are function words that indicate how a noun or noun phrase relates to the rest of the sentence. The correct preposition in this case is ‘than’.
Prepositions should be used carefully because sometimes changing a preposition can change the entire meaning or context of the sentence or phrase.

Question:
In the following question, the sentence given with blank to be filled in with an appropriate word. Select the correct alternative out of the four and indicate it by selecting the appropriate option.
Vivekananda _________ the young to “arise” and “awake”, to reject all doctrines and dogmas that were based on superstition and prejudice.
Solution:
The correct answer is Exhorted.
Key Points
  • The blank in the sentence requires a verb that means to strongly urge or encourage someone to do something.
  • "Exhorted" fits perfectly, as it means to strongly encourage or urge someone to do something. (प्रेरित किया)
  • Vivekananda's role was not about flattering or casually praising, but about inspiring and urging young people towards a higher purpose.
  • The context of the quote is motivational and action-oriented, which matches the meaning of "exhort".
Therefore, the correct answer is 'Option 3'.
Complete Sentence: Vivekananda exhorted the young to “arise” and “awake”, to reject all doctrines and dogmas that were based on superstition and prejudice.
Additional Information
  • Flattered: (चापलूसी की) This means to praise someone, often in a way that is not sincere, in order to get a favorable reaction. It does not fit the context of urging action.
  • Lauded: (प्रशंसा की) This means to praise, but the context of Vivekananda's statement is more aligned with motivation rather than mere praise.
  • Commended: (प्रशंसा की) Similar to lauded, this means to praise formally or officially. It lacks the urgency and action-orientated nuance that "exhorted" conveys.

Question:
In the following question, the sentence given with blank to be filled in with an appropriate word. Select the correct alternative out of the four and indicate it by selecting the appropriate option.
When negative attitudes toward religion, in the West or elsewhere, are motivated by a _________ for justice, they must be respected.
Solution:
The correct answer is "Concern".
Key Points
  • Concern as a verb means relate to, be about and as noun means a matter of interest or importance to someone.
Therefore, the correct answer is "option 2".
Additional Information
  • Disinterest refers to the state of not being influenced by personal involvement in something.
  • Distraction means a thing that prevents someone from concentrating on something else.
  • Association means a connection or cooperative link between people or organizations.

Question:
In the following question, the sentence given with blank to be filled in with an appropriate word. Select the correct alternative out of the four and indicate it by selecting the appropriate option.
The art of growing up is living in the school of life, where learning is _________, and taking responsibility is important.
Solution:
Neglected refers to not receiving proper attention or disregarded.
Ignored means refuse to take notice of or acknowledge something.
Focused refers to pat full attention to something.
Superficial means existing or occurring at or on the surface. Therefore the correct answer is focused as it makes more sense in this context.

Question:
In the following question, the sentence given with blank to be filled in with an appropriate word. Select the correct alternative out of the four and indicate it by selecting the appropriate option.
Walt Disney failed many times, but learned the right lessons and hence failure was not _________ for him.
Solution:
The correct option is 'Frustrating'.
  1. Frustrating is the prevent participle means to prevent from progressing, succeeding, or being fulfilled or a cause to feel upset.
  2. Celebration is the action of celebrating an important day or event.
  3. Argument means an exchange of diverging or opposite views, typically a heated or angry one.
  4. Connector means a thing which links two or more things together.
Out of all the alternatives frustrating makes the most sense in the context.

Question:
In the following question, the sentence given with blank to be filled in with an appropriate word. Select the correct alternative out of the four and indicate it by selecting the appropriate option.
There is now a reasonably _________ body of evidence suggesting that, even from the most rigorous scientific perspective, unselfishness and concern for others are not only in our own interests but also, in a sense, innate to our biological nature.
Solution:
Substantial means of considerable importance, size, or worth.
Small means a size that is less than the normal or usual or insignificant.
Insignificant means too small or unimportant to be worth consideration.
Ethereal means extremely delicate and light in a way that seems not to be of this world.
Out of all the alternatives substantial best fits the context.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which best expresses the meaning of the given word.
Profligate
Solution:
Profligate refers to recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources or licentious; dissolute.
Modest means unassuming in the estimation of one's abilities or achievements.
Extravagant means lacking restraint in spending money or using resources
Upright means (of a person) sitting or standing with the back straight.
Virtuous having or showing high moral standards.
Out of all the alternatives Extravagant best expresses the meaning of profligate.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which best expresses the meaning of the given word.
Oracular
Solution:
Oracular means (of an utterance, advice, etc.) hard to interpret; enigmatic.
Lucid means expressed clearly; easy to understand.
Distinct means recognizably different in nature from something else of a similar type.
Cryptic means having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure or (of a crossword) having difficult clues which indicate the solutions indirectly.
Unambiguous means not open to more than one interpretation.
Out of all the alternatives cryptic is the word with similar meaning to oracular.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which best expresses the meaning of the given word.
Nauseous
Solution:
Nauseous means disgusting or offensive or affected with nausea; feeling inclined to vomit.
Loathsome means causing hatred or disgust; repulsive.
Benevolent refers to well meaning and kindly.
Worthy means having or showing the qualities that deserve the specified action or regard.
Considerable means notably large in size, amount, or extent.
Out of all the alternatives loathsome is word with a similar meaning to nauseous (disgusting or offensive).

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which is opposite in meaning to the given word.
Protract
Solution:
The correct answer is 'Curtail'.
Key Points
  • Protract is a verb that means prolong i.e. to prolong in time or space (बढ़ाना).
    • Example: He had certainly taken his time, even protracting the process.
  • Curtail means "reduce in extent or quantity; impose a restriction on."
  • Hence as per the meaning of both words, it is clear that 'curtail' will be the antonym of 'Protract'.
Let's look at the meaning of other options-
  • Unwise means (of a person or action) not wise or sensible; foolish.
  • Sharp means (of an object) having an edge or point that is able to cut or pierce something.
  • Elongate means to make (something) longer, especially unusually so in relation to its width.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which is opposite in meaning to the given word.
Remnant
Solution:
Remnant means a part or quantity that is left after the greater part has been used, removed, or destroyed.
Whole means all of; entire.
Slice refers to cut from a larger portion.
Fraction means a small or tiny part, amount, or proportion of something.
Part means an amount or section of something.
Out of all the alternatives the word whole is opposite in meaning to remnant.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the one which is opposite in meaning to the given word.
Sneer
Solution:
Sneer means a contemptuous or mocking smile, remark, or tone.
Praise means to express warm approval or admiration of.
Scorn means a feeling and expression of contempt or disdain for someone or something.
Mock means to tease or laugh at in a scornful or contemptuous manner.
Despise means feel contempt or a deep repugnance for.
The word which is opposite in meaning to the given word is 'praise'.

Question: In the following question, four words have been given out of which one word is incorrectly spelt. Select the incorrectly spelt word.
Solution:
Aphorism is the correct spelling. Aphorism means a pithy observation which contains a general truth.

Question: In the following question, four words have been given out of which one word is incorrectly spelt. Select the incorrectly spelt word.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Hornet’s nest
Solution: The literal meaning of the phrase hornet’s nest is a troublesome or hazardous situation. Therefore out of the 4 alternatives 1 is the correct answer.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
In the teeth of
Solution:
The phrase ‘In the teeth of’ means in spite of (opposition or difficulty).
For example: In the teeth of the longest recession since the 1930s, the company continues to perform well.
Out of the alternatives provided, option 2 is therefore the correct answer.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
In a flutter
Solution: The literal meaning of the phrase ‘In a flutter’ is in a state of nervous excitement. Therefore out of the 4 alternatives, option 3 is the correct answer.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
All Greek to me
Solution: The literal meaning of the phrase ‘All Greek to me’ is that something is not understandable. Therefore the correct alternative is option 2 i.e. incomprehensible which also means not understandable.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Mealy mouthed
Solution:
The phrase ‘mealy mouthed’ means being unwilling to speak in a simple or open way because they want to avoid talking directly about something unpleasant.
Therefore out of the alternatives option 3 is the correct answer.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
No love lost
Solution: If there is ‘no love lost’ between two people, they have a strong hatred, hostility, or enmity for the other person, and make no attempt to conceal it. Therefore out of the alternatives given 4 is the correct answer.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Out of sorts
Solution: The phrase ‘out of sorts’ means slightly unwell. Out of the alternatives correct answer is therefore option 2 i.e. to be unwell.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Pay lip service
Solution:
The literal meaning of the phrase ‘pay lip service’ is to express respect, loyalty or support for something insincerely.
Therefore the correct answer is ‘pretend to regard ’.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Rip up old sores
OP4: To deal with a person strictly
Solution: The phrase ‘rip up old sores’ means to revive a quarrel which was almost forgotten. Therefore the correct answer is option 3.

Question:
In the following question, out of the given four alternatives, select the alternative which best expresses the meaning of the Idiom/Phrase.
Rule to roost
Solution: The phrase ‘rule to roost’ means to be in charge or dominate a situation or person or thing. Therefore the correct answer is option 2.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: The main cause of global warming is the human being's careless activities.
Q: There are many causes of the global warming which affects human lives and health in many aspects.
R: Fossil fuels burning for many reasons are highly responsible to increase global warming.
S: Ever increasing human population is demanding more resources to live easy and healthy life such as land to live and for crop cultivation, technological growth for comfort and to deal with increasing temperature of atmosphere, etc.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The first sentence should always introduce the subject of the sentence, to the readers. Sentence Q provides an insight to the readers about the subject that happens to be causes of global warming. No other sentence provides an introduction rather they elaborate and continue the point raised in Q.
Sentence 2- The second sentence is P in the sequence as it is the continuation of sentence Q. When sentence Q began by stating that there are many causes of global warming, sentence P continues the discussion by naming one such cause.
Sentence 3- Sentence S is an explanation to how humans are a major cause of global warming, a point that was raised in sentence P. Therefore it serves as a continuation to sentence P and is next in the sequence.
Sentence 4- Sentence R explains another human activity that is responsible for global warming and is a continuation to sentence S.
Hence, the correct order is QPSR and the correct answer is option 1.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: We need to be more physically healthy and fit to win the current environmental challenges.
Q: It keeps us away from the diseases, infections and other lethal diseases by reducing extra kilos, improving the strength of muscle and bones, increasing immunity level, and maintaining the healthy functioning of our major body organs.
R: In the modern time, where pollution, global warming and other environmental issues have covered us, the importance of health and fitness has increased to a great extent.
S: It helps us to look better with lots of patience and confidence level
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence R provides an insight to the subject of discussion in this paragraph. Therefore it is the first sentence in the sequence. It introduces the subject of health and fitness to the readers of the paragraph quite clearly.
Sentence 2- Sentence P continues the point raised in sentence R and is therefore second in the sequence. It further elaborates that we need to be more physically healthy and fit to win the current environmental challenges, which were mentioned in sentence R.
Sentence 3- Sentence Q begins with ‘it’ which shows the subject from the previous sentence is the subject here as well. The previous sentence talked about the need of physical health and fitness and sentence Q explains the benefit of the same.
Sentence 4- The sentence should always conclude the paragraph and sentence S fulfils this purpose. Sentence S begins with ‘it’ which shows the subject from the previous sentence is the subject here as well. Therefore it is a continuation of sentence Q.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: All these factors together can help eradicate poverty, crimes and disease rates.
Q: Girls’ education is important from every perspective of life and society.
R: Not only do they take right decisions for themselves, but they also provide better education and health care options to their children.
S: Educated women lead a healthier life compared to the uneducated women; they participate in the family matters and in the formal labour markets too; earn well, marry at a considerable age and plan a family in a better manner.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The first sentence should always introduce the subject of the paragraph. Sentence Q quite clearly gives an introduction to the subject of importance of girl’s education.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: We can not only see the beauty of nature in the form of floral and faunal diversity, but can also experience peace in the sylvan surroundings.
Q: A dense collection of trees, plants and other vegetation makes up a forest.
R: Forests are home to a great variety of wildlife such as animals, birds, reptiles and insects.
S: Forests are beautiful natural settings where we can go and experience nature in its splendid expression.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The first sentence should always introduce the subject of the paragraph and that is what sentence Q does here. Sentence Q clearly introduces the subject of forests by explaining its formation in brief.
Sentence 2- Sentence R is a continuation of sentence Q by talking about how forests are home to various wildlife animals.
Sentence 3- Sentence S is a continuation of sentence R and therefore next in sequence. Like the previous sentence this sentence also explains the features or beauty of forests.
Sentence 4- Sentence P concludes the discussion. It talks about how we not only limited, to enjoy the beauty of flora and fauna of that place but also experience peace in nature.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: Honesty is an important principle that must govern our lives.
Q: Honesty is reflected in our words and deeds.
R: When we speak the truth we state the facts as they are.
S: We may find it convenient to avoid telling the truth, but if we are honest we should say the truth whatever may be the repercussions.
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence P introduces the subject of the paragraph i.e. honesty and its importance in life.
Sentence 2- Sentence Q further talks about how our words and deeds reflect honesty.
Sentence 3 – Sentence R is a continuation to sentence Q which explained that are words and deeds reflect honesty. Sentence R further explains how this happens.
Sentence 4- Sentence S concludes the paragraph. It is a continuation of the previous sentence which said that when we speak the truth we state the facts as they are. This sentence further continues by saying that we may sometimes find it convenient to avoid telling the truth, but if we are honest we should say the truth whatever may be the repercussions.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: We can be kind to human beings who need our help.
Q: Kindness is a quality that human beings show in various ways.
R: We can also be kind to other life forms like dogs, cats and other pets and domesticated animals, and to wildlife like birds and animals.
S: We can be kind to our family members, relatives, friends and neighbours.
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence Q introduces the subject of the paragraph which is kindness a quality.
Sentence 2- Sentence P further states that we can be kind to people who need our help. Thereby continuing the discussion that began in sentence Q.
Sentence 3- Sentence S is next in continuation to the previous sentence by providing more examples of people who we can be kind with.
Sentence 4- Sentence R takes the discussion further, expanding the life forms with whom we can be kind, like dogs, cats and other pets and domesticated animals, and to wildlife like birds and animals.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: If we spend the twenty-four hours that we have in a day in an efficient way we can be successful in completing the tasks and achieving our goals for the day.
Q: If we wish to succeed in achieving our short term and long term goals we need to manage our time effectively.
R: If we waste our time on vain activities we either get stressed out doing the tasks we need to do or fail to do what needs to be done.
S: We all have the same number of hours at our disposal each day.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The first sentence should always introduce the subject of the paragraph. Sentence S provides an insight to the reader that the subject is time. All other sentences explain the same subject but don’t introduce it.
Sentence 2- Sentence P is a continuation of the previous sentence and an elaborate explanation of what the writer wants to convey on the subject ‘time’. The context of the sentence is time management if done efficiently will lead to successful completion of our goals and tasks.
Sentence 3- Sentence R explains what happens when we waste time, in contrast to the previous sentence which was about time management. These two contrasting sentence are together in the sequence, as sentence R serves as a repercussion if don’t manage our time (from the previous sentence).
Sentence 4- The last sentence should always conclude the paragraph. Sentence Q concludes the paragraph by a message or lesson for the readers. It states that if we wish to succeed in achieving our short term and long term goals we need to manage our time effectively.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: But when it comes to negative human rights reports or one on the environment, it rubbishes them.
Q: This kind of behaviour isn’t going to solve the problem.
R: Every government is quick to accept reports that give it a pat on the back – as the Indian government was after the latest ease of doing business report.
S: No government likes negative reports on its performance.
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence S provides an insight about the subject of the paragraph that has been talked about in the other sentence as well but only introduced in this sentence in specific.
Sentence 2- Sentence R is a continuation of sentence S which stated that no government likes negative reports. This sentence continues that point and states that every government is quick to accept reports that give it a pat on the back.
Sentence 3- Sentence P starts with ‘But’ which explains that the subject of the previous sentence must be subject here as well. This sentence further continues the discussion.
Sentence 4- Sentence Q is a continuation of the previous sentence as it begins with ‘this’ which means that the subject of the previous sentence must be subject here as well.
The previous sentence was about how negative reports rubbishes the governments and this sentence says that this type of behavior is not right.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: The Great Depression that began on Black Tuesday, 1929 plunged the worldwide recession.
Q: The years between the first and second world wars were a time of instability.
R: Coming to power in 1933, Hitler capitalized on this economic decline and the deep German resentment due to the emasculating Treaty of Versailles, signed following the armistice of 1918.
S: Declaring that Germany needed Lebensraum or “living space,” Hitler began to test the Western powers and their willingness to monitor the treaty’s provision.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The sentence Q, provides an introduction to the subject that happens to the time period between the 2 world wars.
Sentence 2- Sentence P talks about the major issue between this period(from previous sentence) i.e. the great depression.
Sentence 3- Sentence R further explains how Hitler responded to this economic depression and therefore this sentence is next in sequence.
Sentence 4- Sentence S is a continuation of the previous sentence. This sentence further explains the impact of great depression in Germany and Hitler’s response to the same.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: One’s language fluency is determined by the quality of reading.
Q: In all cultures and civilizations, much stress is laid on reading but, in the modern times, this activity is being ignored.
R: Reading is an essential basic skills building activity.
S: Besides, vocabulary enrichment, ideas collection, familiarization with different types of writing formats, speaking fluency, etc, all depend upon reading.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The first sentence should always introduced the subject of the paragraph. Sentence R provides an insight on the subject matter of the paragraph that is reading. The sentence tells us that reading is an essential skill building activity.
Sentence 2- The next sentence in this sequence is sentence P. It further explains how someone’s language fluency is also determined by the quality of reading.
Sentence 3- Sentence S is next in sequence as it explains the other things such as vocabulary enrichment, ideas collection, familiarization with different types of writing formats, speaking fluency that are also dependent on reading apart from language fluency. This is evident from the word ‘besides’, the sentence begins with besides showing how the discussion is continued.
Sentence 4- The last sentence should always conclude the paragraph. Sentence Q talks about how reading has lost its importance in modern times.
Hence, the correct order is RPSQ and the correct answer is option 4.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: Young boys and girls seem to have become inordinately addicted to these sites.
Q: The parents, teachers and the government must look into the problems being caused by these networking sites and must formulate a strategy either to curb or completely stop its fast growing negative influence on the minds of our youth.
R: Smart-phones, computers, social media, internet and networking sites such as Facebook and Twitter have become source of major distractions for students.
S: They are thoughtlessly and uselessly wasting their precious time on these sites.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The first sentence should always introduce the subject matter of the paragraph. Sentence R introduces the subject of social media and technology serving as major distractions for students.
Sentence 2- Sentence P is a continuation of the previous subject. It explains how the young generation is addicted to these social media sites (explained in sentence R).
Sentence 3- Sentence S begins with ‘these’ which means the subject of the previous sentence is also the subject here. The context of this sentence is also similar to sentence P that is why this sentence is next in sequence.
Sentence 4- Sentence Q provides a conclusion to the discussion, by giving a measure to control the problem of excessive use of social media by the younger generation.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: Recycling basically involves turning used materials that are labelled as recyclable over to your local waste facility designated in a disposal container as “recyclable” materials to be taken and reused as material for a new purpose.
Q: Not only are natural resources limited, but recycling efforts can significantly reduce additional waste that will not only harm the planet today, but future generations as well.
R: A recyclable product is turned back into a raw form that can be used to create a new and different product.
S: The natural resources on our planet earth are limited so we must make the most to conserve, recycle and reuse whenever possible.
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence P introduces the subject of Recycling and provides a detailed explanation of the same. It explains the process of recycling.
Sentence 2- Sentence R is a continuation of sentence P therefore is next in sequence. It talks about a recycled product whose formation was explained in the previous sentence.
Sentence 3- Sentence S explains the need of recycling. It states that the natural resources on our planet earth are limited so we must make the most to conserve, recycle.
Sentence 4- Sentence Q is a continuation of the point raised in sentence S. It states that not only are the resource limited (a point raised in S) but recycling also helps reducing waste in general.
Hence, the correct order is PRSQ and the correct answer is option 1.

S: Your confidence may be low too and you will not believe in your ability to be successful.
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence P introduces the subject of the paragraph that is low self-esteem. The first line of every paragraph should introduce the subject and this is what sentence P does here.
Sentence 2- Sentence R is next in sequence as it is a continuation of the previous sentence. This evident from the words ‘if you feel like this’, sentence P was about how low esteem makes us feel about ourselves, and sentence R refers to the exact same feeling.
Sentence 3- Sentence S is next in sequence as it elaborates the effects of low esteem, just like sentence R did.
Sentence 4- The last sentence should always round off the paragraph and that is why sentence Q is last in the sequence. It rounds off whatever has been said in the previous sentences.
Hence, the correct order is PRSQ and the correct answer is option 1.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: This would bring a sense of closure to an issue that has seen about two decades of wrangling.
Q: By clearing the path for 49 percent foreign investment in Air India (AI), the Centre has finally decided to push ahead on its privatisation.
R: While the parliamentary standing committee on AI privatisation is yet to express its views, a sort of political consensus appears to be close at hand.
S: There cannot be a more opportune time to push ahead with disinvestment; this, ironically, is despite the fact that the airline has improved its operational performance.
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence Q clearly introduces the subject of the paragraph that is the policy of Privatisation in Air India. All the other sentences explain the same subject but not introduce it as clearly as Q.
Sentence 2- Sentence P begins with ‘this’ which means it is a continuation of the previous sentence. This here refers to the policy of privatisation in Air India. So sentence P is next in sequence.
Sentence 3- Sentence R is next in sequence as it talks about the fact that the parliamentary committee is yet to react on the policy that was explained in the previous lines.
Sentence 4- Sentence S concludes the paragraph by providing another side of the discussion that there could not be a more opportune time to push ahead with disinvestment; this, ironically, happened after the airlines had improved its operational performance.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: The depletion of organic nutrients in the soil has reached alarming proportions, thanks to indiscriminate use of chemical fertiliser in Green Revolution areas.
Q: As against an acceptable level of ‘soil organic carbon’ of well over 5 percent, soils in Punjab are said to have levels far below 1 percent.
R: Besides, 5.3 billion tonnes of soil is eroded annually, at a rate of 16.4 tonnes/hectare.
S: The nutrient imbalance has been skewed by the overuse of urea (N) vis-a-vis phosphatic (P in chemical parlance) and potassic (K) fertiliser.
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence P introduces the subject of the paragraph and that is why the first sentence in sequence. The subject here is the effects of the excessive use of chemicals during Green Revolution.
Sentence 2-Sentence Q is next in sequence as it elaborates the point of depletion of soil nutrients, raised in sentence P.
Sentence 3-Sentence R begins with ‘besides’ which means it is a continuation of the previous sentence. It provides another fact in the matter.
Sentence 4- Sentence S is last in sequence as it provides a conclusion to the paragraph.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: While it is good to see SEBI taking a serious view of leaks and initiating suo motu action, bringing the perpetrators to book through such old-fashioned methods may be an uphill task.
Q: But recent episodes of suspected insider trading through WhatsApp groups, in which analysts shared prescient tip-offs about upcoming results for top listed companies, reveals that the framework remains porous.
R: The Ministry of Corporate Affairs and the Securities Exchange Board of India (SEBI) have lately redoubled their efforts to put in place a water-tight governance framework for listed firms.
S: Initiating a probe into this episode, SEBI has interrogated analysts, conducted raids on stock brokers and deployed search-and-seizure powers to confiscate laptops and mobile phones.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The first sentence should always introduce the subject of the paragraph.
Sentence 2- Sentence Q begins with ‘but’ which means it is a continuation of the previous sentence. Sentence Q is continuation of sentence R and therefore next in sequence.
Sentence 3-Sentence S a continuation of sentence Q. Both sentences have the same subjects i.e. the recent episodes of insider trading.
Sentence 4- The last sentence in the sequence is sentence P as it concludes the paragraph.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: The philosophy of pragmatism goes something like this.
Q: It is not possible for the mind to relate to anything other than ideas.
R: The mind is such that it deals only with ideas.
S: Therefore, it is not correct to think that the mind actually can ponder reality.
Solution:
Sentence 1- Sentence P introduces the subject of the paragraph i.e. pragmatism
Sentence 2- Sentence R is next in sequence as it is the continuation of the point raised in sentence P.
Sentence 3- Sentence Q talks about how it is not possible for the mind to relate to anything other than ideas. A similar point to the one stated in R i.e. the mind only deals with ideas.
Sentence 4- Sentence S is a conclusion to the paragraph, as it states that since the mind relates only to ideas (something discussed in the previous lines) therefore, it is not correct to think that the mind actually can ponder reality.
Hence, the correct order is PRQS and the correct answer is option 3.

Question:
The question below consists of a set of labelled sentences. These sentences, when properly sequenced form a coherent paragraph. Select the most logical order of sentences from among the options.
P: The basic reform they need is to change their holding structure to give them autonomy, as well as accountability, not a promise of no government interference.
Q: PSBs need systemic reform to overhaul their current decision-making structure and culture.
R: If the government does not want to free the banks from majority state ownership, it could at least put them at arm’s remove, by creating a holding company that would hold the PSB equity, appoint PSB boards and supervise their functioning.
S: It is surprising that after appointing the Banks Board Bureau, it has been given little role in reforming the PSBs.
Solution:
Sentence 1- The first line should always introduce the subject of the paragraph, and that is what sentence Q does here. The subject here is PSBs need systemic reform to overhaul their current decision-making structure and culture.
Sentence 2- Sentence P is a continuation of the previous sentence as this sentence elaborates on the basic reform that PSBs need to work on. A point raised in Q.
Sentence 3-Sentence R provides another solution or suggestion in this case on the matter of PSBs.
Sentence 4- Sentence S is a conclusion to the paragraph, as it provides another seperate fact in the matter being discussed.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
A person employed to drive a private hired car.
Solution:
Amateur a person who engages in a pursuit, especially a sport, on an unpaid basis.
Chauffeur is a person employed to drive a private hired car.
Connoisseur is an expert judge in matters of taste.
Provocateur is an undercover agent who incites suspected persons to partake in or commit criminal acts.
Therefore the correct answer is 2.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute for the phrase.
Costing nothing.
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 3) i.e. Gratis
Key Points
  • The meaning of the words given in the option are:
    • Fortis means strongly articulated, especially more so than another consonant articulated in the same place.
    • Glottis means the part of the larynx consisting of the vocal cords and the slit-like opening between them. It affects voice modulation through expansion or contraction.
    • Gratis refers given or done for nothing; free.
    • Abatis means a defence made of felled trees placed lengthwise over each other with the boughs pointing outwards
  • Therefore the meaning that is similar to the phrase ‘costing nothing’ is gratis.
Additional Information
  • Gratis comes from the Latin word for "favor;" so in English a party favor is a small item given gratis to everyone attending a party.
  • Gratis is used as both an adjective ("The drinks were gratis") and an adverb ("Drinks were served gratis"). But however it's used, it means "free".

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
Any new participant in some activity.
Solution:
Neophyte means a person who is new to a subject or activity.
Holophytic means being able to synthesize complex organic compounds by photosynthesis.
Mesophyte is a plant needing only a moderate amount of water.
Epiphyte is a plant that grows on another plant, especially one that is not parasitic, such as the numerous ferns, bromeliads, air plants, and orchids growing on tree trunks in tropical rainforests.
Therefore the correct answer here is 1.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
A person who lives by himself.
Solution:
Bemuse means puzzle, confuse, or bewilder.
Recluse refers to a person who lives a solitary life and tends to avoid other people or lives alone.
Applause means approval or praise expressed by clapping.
Abstruse means difficult to understand; obscure.
Therefore the correct answer here is option 2

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
Not allowing fluid to pass-through.
Solution:
Envious means feeling or showing envy.
Impervious refers to not allowing fluid to pass through.
Concious means aware of and responding to one's surroundings.
Nauseous means affected with nausea; feeling inclined to vomit. Therefore the correct answer is option 2.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
A place where animals are slaughtered for consumption as food.
Solution:
Reservoir means a large natural or artificial lake used as a source of water supply.
Abattoir means a slaughterhouse.
Memoir refers to a historical account or biography written from personal knowledge.
Peignoir is a woman's light dressing gown or negligee.
Therefore the correct answer is option 2.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
One who runs away from justice.
Solution:
Plaintive means sounding sad and mournful.
Fugitive is a person who has escaped from captivity or is in hiding.
Accretive is the process of accretion, which is growth or increase by gradual addition, in finance and general nomenclature.
Adventives is a species that is not native and usually not yet well established, as exotic plants or animals.
Therefore the correct answer is 2.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
A slight fault that can be forgiven.
Solution:
The given answer is Venial.
Key Points
  • Venial means (of a fault or offence) slight and pardonable.
  • Bovial is an adjective meaning of or pertaining to cattle.
  • Aerial means existing, happening, or operating in the air.
  • Xenial means relating to, or constituting hospitality or relations between host and guest and especially among the ancient Greeks between persons of different cities.
Therefore, the correct answer here is option 1 Venial.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
A paradise with perfect bliss.
Solution:
The epineurium is the outermost layer of dense irregular connective tissue surrounding a peripheral nerve.
Elysium is the place at the ends of the earth to which certain favoured heroes were conveyed by the gods after death and as a noun an Elysium is a place or state of perfect happiness.
Encomium is a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.
Eulogium a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly, especially a tribute to someone who has just died.
Therefore the correct answer here is Elysium.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
A story that expresses ideas through symbols.
Solution:
Armoury is a place where weapons are kept.
Allegory is a story, poem, or picture that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning, through symbols.
Amatory is relating to or induced by sexual love or desire.
Aleatory = depending on the throw of a dice or on chance; random.
Therefore the correct answer here is option 2.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
A period of interval between two regimes and governments.
Solution:
Polygonum is a plant of a genus that includes knotgrass and knotweed, some of which are weeds and some are garden ornamentals.
Magnum is a wine bottle of twice the standard size, normally 1 1/2 litres. In US, it can also mean a gun designed to fire cartridges that are more powerful than its calibre would suggest.
Interregnum is a period when the normal government is suspended, especially between successive reigns or regimes. Or more simply, an interval or pause between two periods of office or other things.
Presternum is the anterior segment of the sternum of a mammal.
Therefore the correct answer here is 3.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute of the phrase.
A decision made by public voting.
Solution:
Anthracite is coal of a hard variety that contains relatively pure carbon and burns with little flame and smoke.
Chalcocite is a black or gray lustrous metallic mineral that consists of a sulfide of copper and is an important copper ore.
Plebiscite the direct vote of all the members of an electorate on an important public question such as a change in the constitution.
Reincite refers to incite again.
Therefore the correct answer here is option 3.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
My sister (has ordered for) a new mobile phone.
Solution: From all the alternatives ‘order’ and ‘has ordered to’ does not fit the context grammatically, and do not fit the sentence. Therefore the correct answer is ‘has ordered’.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
On a holiday, Priya (prefers reading than going) shopping.
Solution: Out of the options given, 2 is the correct answer. ‘Prefers reading rather going’ and ‘preferred reading to go’ are grammatically incorrect in the context of the sentence. Therefore the correct answer is ‘prefers reading to going’.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
In an industry where programmers search in (vain) for fresh ideas, it is no wonder that attention spans are short and cliche is king.
Solution:
From the given alternatives, Vain refers to producing no result; useless.
Wain is a wagon or cart. Wane refers to have a progressively smaller part of its visible surface illuminated so that it appears to decrease in size and vein is the name of a human nerve.
Therefore, none of the words fit the context better than Vain, therefore there is no need for improvement.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
The famous Dr. Gupta (is only) physician in our village.
Solution:
From the given alternatives, ‘is the only’ is the correct answer.
‘Is a only’ is grammatically incorrect keeping in mind the rules of vowels and grammar.
‘Is an only’ does not fit in the sentence grammatically since here we are referring to a specific doctor, Dr Gupta that is why ‘an’ cannot be used.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
My cousins insisted that I should watch the documentary (from beginning to the end).
OP2: from the beginning to the end
Solution:
The correct answer is from the beginning to the end
Key Points
  • In the given sentence it is clear that they are talking about a particular documentary.
  • And they are referring to the beginning and the end of that specific documentary.
  • While mentioning things that are specific, and things which the speaker knows about we use the definite article.
  • The definite article is used to talk about things that are used in particular.
  • In the given sentence the specific documentary and it's beginning and end.
  • Thus we should use from the beginning to the end as we are talking about something in particular.
  • Therefore the correct answer here is ‘from the beginning to the end’.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
I wouldn’t abase myself (by get) into an argument with him.
Solution:
From the given alternatives, ‘on get’ is incorrect because the sentence is framed in past continuous tense and ‘on get’ is present tense. ‘In getting’ is grammatically incorrect with respect to the context of the sentence, ‘into’ is already present in the sentence.
Therefore the correct answer is ‘by getting’, and option 3 is correct.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Kanika accepted the invitation (on) alacrity.
Solution: From the given alternatives ‘with’ is the correct answer. The word alacrity means brisk and cheerful readiness, so the words ‘in’, ‘on’ and ‘from’ are grammatically incorrect.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
A captious attitude (causes often) difficulties in a relationship.
Solution:
From the given alternatives ‘caused often’ and ‘causing often’ are grammatically incorrect with respect to the context of the sentence.
Often is an adverb and it should precede the verb 'causes' in this context.
The correct answer here would be ‘often causes’.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
She broke down at his words uttered with blatant disregard for a (personal’s) feelings.
Solution: From the given alternatives, ‘personnel’s’ means people employed in an organization therefore it does not fit the context of the statement. ‘Person’ is grammatically in correct here. So the correct answer is ‘person’s’.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
His decision (will be fair) to everyone as he is the most disinterested party in this controversy.
Solution:
The correct answer is No improvement.
Key Points
  • The given sentence is in the active voice of the future tense and the verb be is the main verb here.
  • The word fair is an adjective and hence it is correctly placed here which means appropriate and acceptable in a particular situation (उचित, सही).
    • Example: That’s a fair price for that house.
  • All the other given alternatives are grammatically incorrect concerning the context of the sentence and the correct answer would be ‘will be fair’.
  • Therefore, there is no need for improvement.
The correct choice is option 4.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
She dithered every time she (make) a decision.
Solution:
From the given alternatives ‘makes’ and ‘will makes’ does not fit the tense of the sentence.
‘Makes’ is present tense and ‘will make’ is future tense, while the sentence is framed in past tense.
Therefore the correct answer here is ‘had to make’.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
She emanated ebullience as she (learn) about her first rank in the exam.
Solution: From the given alternatives, ‘leaning’ does not fit the tense of the sentence; ‘learning’ is continuous present tense, while the sentence is framed in past tense. ‘Had learn’ is grammatically incorrect. Therefore the correct answer here is ‘learnt’

Question:
Directions: Improve the bracketed part of the sentence by choosing the correct option given out of four.
The student who (chosen) to represent the school was the epitome of dedication and excellence.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1) i.e. 'Chose'
  • As the sentence is in the simple past tense, hence, the second form of the verb will be in use here.
  • Also, because, both the states of actions are in the same tense, hence, the form of the verbs will be in the same tense (V2)
  • Keeping the same thing in mind, the sentence, after correction, is supposed to be:
    • ​The student who chose to represent the school was the epitome of dedication and excellence.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Life in (more) thriving towns is intimately connected with the local trades and industries.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
Here, the superlative form of the adjective(in this specific case, a determiner) 'many' has been used to signify that life in almost all thriving towns is intimately connected with the local trades and industries.
Much' is an adjective of the positive degree generally used to qualify uncountable nouns, which clearly is not the case here. A 'town' is a countable noun.
Note: Many>More>Most (increase in degree as we move from left to right)

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Keshav was (endowed on) rare talents.
Solution:
The word endowed means provided/blessed with a quality, ability, or asset. The context of the sentence is that Keshav is provided/blessed with rare talents.
From the given alternatives, keeping in mind the meaning of the word the correct answer is ‘endowed with’ because ‘endowed of’, ‘endowed on’ are grammatically incorrect and ‘endowed upon’ does not fit the context of the sentence.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
The unpleasant feeling (passes) and she glanced guardedly up at him.
Solution:
From the given alternatives the correct answer is ‘passed’.
‘Passes’ and ‘passing’ are incorrect as they don’t match the tense of the sentence. On the other hand ‘has passed’ is grammatically in correct in this context.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Affirmations are positive statements that (describes) a desired situation or goal and are often repeated, in order to get them impressed on the subconscious mind.
Solution:
The correct answer is Describe.
Key Points
Reading the above sentence we find that:
  • Affirmations are positive statements is a plural subject.
  • Therefore the verb should agree with it. Thus describes is wrong and we should use the plural verb 'describe'.
  • ‘Describing’ and ‘is describing’ are grammatically incorrect in the context of the sentence and the tenses do not match the tense of the sentence.
Thus the correct answer is Option 2 i.e Describe.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Through the practice of repeated affirmations, we can make great progress on our chosen path and (increasing) our magnetism to succeed in anything.
Solution:
From the given alternatives, the correct answer is ‘increase’.
‘Have increased’ and ‘increased’ are grammatically incorrect in the context of the sentence.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Everybody is aware that peaceful life respects non-violence and non-interference, yet it is difficult (to maintaining) peace only because public consciousness is not expansive enough to fully understand peace.
Solution:
From the given alternatives, ‘to maintain’ is the correct answer.
‘Maintaining’ and ‘maintained’ are grammatically incorrect in the context of the sentence and do not match with the tense of the sentence.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
A beautiful landscape, full of green vegetation, will not just attract our attention but (fill us) with infinite satisfaction.
Solution:
The correct answer is "No Improvement".
Key Points
  • The phrase in question, "fill us," is appropriately used in the context of the sentence, indicating what the landscape will do to "us" (the viewers or experiencers of the landscape).
  • The tense and subject of the phrase correctly align with the rest of the sentence, which is presented in the future tense and focuses on the effect on "us."
  • Option 1 ("Will fill us") adds an unnecessary future tense marker given that "will not just attract" already sets the sentence in the future tense, making it redundant.
  • Option 2 ("Filled us") incorrectly shifts the verb tense to the past, disrupting the future-oriented context of the sentence.
  • Option 3 ("Fill them") changes the pronoun, which alters the intended subject from "us" to "them," potentially misdirecting the context of who is being satisfied by the landscape.
  • Maintaining "fill us" preserves the sentence's original meaning and grammatical integrity.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is "No improvement".
Note: Official answer is "Option 1".

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
Diversity typically provides fresh perspectives on issues, but it makes it more difficult (to unit) the team and reach agreements.
Solution:
From the given alternatives, the correct answer is ‘to unify’.
‘Unity’ is the wrong word in the context of the sentence, and just ‘unify’ would be grammatically incorrect.
Hence, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Improve the bracketed part of the sentence.
It is dangerous and harmful to be guided in our life’s course by hatreds and aversions, for they are wasteful of energy and limit and twist the mind, and prevent it (to perceiving) the truth.
Solution:
The correct answer is: 'From perceiving'.
Key Points
  • Prevent is followed by the preposition from, not to.
  • Here, perceiving is used as a present participle.
  • Present Participle will be used where the action is incomplete. In the Present participle, (V1+ ing) will be used which works as an adjective before a noun.
  • For Example: India is one of the developing countries in the world.
Therefore, the correct sentence is: 'It is dangerous and harmful to be guided in our life’s course by hatreds and aversions, for they are wasteful of energy and limit and twist the mind, and prevent it from perceiving the truth'.

Question:
A passage is given with five questions following it. Read the passage carefully and select the best answer to each question out of the given four alternatives.
Just as space permeates everything in the universe, love permeates every part, every aspect of creation. If there is one answer to the question, “How and why does this world exist?” the answer, in one word, is ‘Love’. Rather, the answer is ‘Pure Love’, since the word ‘love’ has lost its meaning.
Your very existence is an expression of pure unconditional love of the Source (you may call it Consciousness, Creator, God, Divine Self). This is the truth of your being.
True love transcends both love and hatred. It is unconditional, unquestioning, boundless, unchanging love. It is overflowing love of the Source for the Source through all of creation. True love is way beyond the personalized love that two or more individuals assert on one another. Personalized love, though apparently selfless, is rooted in desires and conditional satisfaction.
We have been brought up in a society that judges love based on conditions. We have been made to believe that we can receive love only when we fit into people’s expectations. If we are not good enough, we will be deprived of love.
These beliefs have influenced the collective psyche of families, groups, communities, and societies since generations to such an extent that love has been reduced to fear of denial.
We need to shift from the paradigm of false conditional love to the essence of pure unconditional love .
The experience of true love comes with surrender of the false ‘I’, in letting go of the feeling of separateness. Without this sacrifice, it is not possible to attain divine love. When this separate ‘I’ is discarded, you embrace everything in oneness and catch a glimpse of pure love.
True love can be experienced only through giving, not by demanding. People who exist in your life are not here to love you. They are here to remind you that you are the Source of Love.
By knowing that you are the Source of love, you can love yourself, instead of waiting to receive love from the world. Ask yourself, “Why do I need an agent to love myself?” Waiting for the world to love you, is like hiring an agent to love yourself!
It is time for you to honour yourself as the Source of love. You have undertaken this human journey to realize and express the boundless love that you truly are.

Question:
What can be the suitable title to the passage ?
Solution: A suitable title for the passage could be ‘Understanding the true love’. The passage talks about true love and its importance in human life. As per the passage true love is unconditional, unquestioning and boundless. It explains of various ways that help us experience true love and distinctly identify its sources.

Question:
What does ‘source’ refers to in the last line of the second para of the passage?

True love can be experienced only through giving, not by demanding. People who exist in your life are not here to love you. They are here to remind you that you are the Source of Love.
By knowing that you are the Source of love, you can love yourself, instead of waiting to receive love from the world. Ask yourself, “Why do I need an agent to love myself?” Waiting for the world to love you, is like hiring an agent to love yourself!
It is time for you to honour yourself as the Source of love. You have undertaken this human journey to realize and express the boundless love that you truly are.

Solution: According to passage the statement of option 2 is incorrect. Certain beliefs have influenced the collective psyche of families, groups, communities, and societies since generations to such an extent that this conditional love has been reduced to fear of denial.

Question:

Just as space permeates everything in the universe, love permeates every part, every aspect of creation. If there is one answer to the question, “How and why does this world exist?” the answer, in one word, is ‘Love’. Rather, the answer is ‘Pure Love’, since the word ‘love’ has lost its meaning.
Your very existence is an expression of pure unconditional love of the Source (you may call it Consciousness, Creator, God, Divine Self). This is the truth of your being.
True love transcends both love and hatred. It is unconditional, unquestioning, boundless, unchanging love. It is overflowing love of the Source for the Source through all of creation. True love is way beyond the personalized love that two or more individuals assert on one another. Personalized love, though apparently selfless, is rooted in desires and conditional satisfaction.
We have been brought up in a society that judges love based on conditions. We have been made to believe that we can receive love only when we fit into people’s expectations. If we are not good enough, we will be deprived of love.
These beliefs have influenced the collective psyche of families, groups, communities, and societies since generations to such an extent that love has been reduced to fear of denial.
We need to shift from the paradigm of false conditional love to the essence of pure unconditional love .
